item.title: DMG Races
item.content:encoded:
With the work towards finalizing and front-page-ifying the new lineages pages, I got thinking towards something I loosely remembered, and, today had found it:

The DMG has in it, a bunch of additional, non standard races. These include things such as gnolls, zombies, skeletons and grimlocks.

So, I'm wondering what peoples thoughts are towards them, and whether they should be added.

On one opinion, they are listed as NPC races, and the book in discussing them describes them as intended to be used for DM's making NPC's (Some of the races on that same list already had player races, but the NPC race version of them exists as a simplified form of them). So, odds are these weren't really made with players in mind (and well, items such as the skeleton have stats such as +1+2-6-4-4 in their arrays)

On the other hand, the Oathbreaker Paladin and the Death Cleric are also DMG subclasses, and they are listed on the wikidot.

But then, against that argument, is the fact the DMG does go out of its way to discuss these races as player options

So yeah, I wanted to hear other people heres thoughts on it. Personally, on one hand, they are race options in an official WoTC book, but on the other, they most definitely do not feel like they are designed for players (as can tell with things like abilities that are +1 to hit all attacks, which work for NPCs, but not players), and they are also sorta hidden in the book.

If we did add them, I feel we'd need to go out of our way somewhere to point out that they would be very, very non standard, (probably more so than the homebrew we list on the wikidot even), since I feel theyd need a bit of context to explain them, and I wouldn't want to have a new player who uses the site use them without said knowledge

Plus, it does feel aimed at DMs, so it might not match the wikidots usual "player focused" attitude.

Yeah, that about sums it up for me. Just wanted to bring them up for the sake of discussion and so as that we were all aware of them if we were not already

Oh, if you want to take a look at the races yourself, they're on the table on page 282 of the DMG

item.title: Missing errata from the Conjuration Wizard page
item.description: Minor Conjuration (p. 116) description changed
item.content:encoded:
On the Conjuration Wizard page:
The object disappears after 1 hour, when you use this feature again, or if it takes any damage.

The Minor Conjuration feature (p.116) received an errata in 2018 that is missing from the wikidot page.
It should now read:
The object disappears after 1 hour, when you use this feature again, or if it takes or deals any damage.

I believe this was added to prevent abuse with Purple Worm poison and similar items.

item.title: Distinguishing non Standard content
item.description: Should the wikidot make better effort to distinguish between content from standard sources and setting specific sources
item.content:encoded:
With the release of Strixhaven meaning we will be adding the content from the book to the website, it's had me thinking about the way this website presents content from non-standard settings (partially due to the concerns for balance with some of said content within the book)

the current form of the website doesn't do too much really, aside from seperating some stuff on the frontpage, such as 'setting specific races', however with the fact that many people use this website to learn more about the game, I feel the website should take better effort to distinguish between core and non-standard content. Especially since, with the release of Strixhaven, the dev's are basically announcing their intent to have different settings have different amounts of player balance. (Strixhaven backgrounds give a free feat. And for older examples, the Ravnica backgrounds added extra spells to your class spell list)

[Content] is part of the [setting] setting, and may not be designed for play outside of its original setting. Check with your DM whether it is good to use if you are going to be using it in play

or something along those lines, just to denote that the content is not usually part of the 'base game'. I mean, I feel like we have a sorta responsibility to try to make the game easier on others, especially others who are getting into the game, since we do run a website like this, and making stuff clear that its not part of the normal should be something we should do.

Yeah the sources exist, but if you're a new player, something saying 'Source: Unearthed Arcana 1', 'Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything' or 'Source: Strixhaven: Curriculum of Chaos' is kinda meaningless, if they even do read them

item.title: D&D 5E - Missing feature from the Armorer subclass (Artificer)
item.description: The Armorer subclass page is missing a feature
item.content:encoded:
Hi,
I just noticed that the page on the Armorer subclass for the Artificer is missing a feature.

On pages 15 and 16 of Tasha's Cauldron of Everything, at Level 3 it says:
"You gain the following benefits while wearing this armor:
- If the armor normally has a Strength requirement, the arcane armor lacks this requirement for you.
- You can use the arcane armor as a spellcasting focus for your artificer spells.
- The armor attaches to you and can’t be removed against your will. It also expands to cover your entire body, although you can retract or deploy the helmet as a bonus action. The armor replaces any missing limbs, functioning identically to a body part it is replacing.
- You can doff or don the armor as an action.
The armor continues to be Arcane Armor until you don another suit of armor or you die."

The part that says "you can doff or don the armor as an action" is missing from the wikidot page.

item.title: DnD Evolutions
item.description: A brief conversation regarding the upcoming dnd edition
item.content:encoded:
"I can actually reveal today that we have earlier this year - we began work on the next evolution of Dungeons and Dragons - new versions of the Core Rule Books, which will be coming out in 2024 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Dungeons and Dragons … with the surveys we have been giving out … the next evolution of the game … we are doing the best to give you the version of the game that you really want; so we can't really say much more yet about what our plans are, as we are still making them; but you are gonna see more surveys like that …. next year - the timing is next year, so next year we will have plenty more to say about those books and what they mean for D&D …. one thing by the way I can assure you these new versions of the books are gonna be completely compatible with all those 5th Edition products that you already own and love and all those products that we will release between now and then …. so next year we will have more to say."

So, in the recent dnd celebration livestreams, we have basically just been handing a 3 year heads up for whats most likely going to be a 5.5e, or at the very least a revamp of all the core rulebooks

The good news is that it will be backwards compatible

So, while its way to early to create a plan for how we're going to integrate what they throw at us to the website, since well, we dont have a clue for atleast a good while, but its sorta a good idea to plan ahead for things we know they might throw at us

We do know the recent survey we got from WoTC basically asked for feedback on the entirety of the PHB classes, so odds are we could be looking at revisions for basically all the phb player content, in otherwords, all the PHB player content

So, would we move the old PHB stuff to a '5.0e' section, just as we move abandoned UA, and then have the new versions on the front page?

And this is assuming the rules change too drastically hopefully, but since its supposed to be backwards compatiable, odds are most of the current stuff on the site, aside from phb stuff, should be fine

Idunno, thoughts?

item.title: Wizard spellbook rules update
item.description: Old text in spellbook copying rules
item.content:encoded:
Hello!

So I think the 'Copying a spell into the book' section in the general wizard class page is out of date. Recent published PHB and also on D&D Beyond have the text as:

"When you find a wizard spell of 1st level or higher, you can add it to your spellbook if it is of a spell level you can prepare and if you can spare the time to decipher and copy it."

Currently, I think the version on this wiki is the original print where it says:

"When you find a wizard spell of 1st level or higher, you can add it to your spellbook if it is of a level for which you have spell slots and if you can spare the time to decipher and copy it."

Usually doesn't matter for a single class wizard but it wreaks havoc when there's a 1+ Spellcaster / Lvl 1 Wizard multiclass haha

item.title: Custom Origin page incorrect

item.content:encoded:
Custom Origin page is currently showing (incorrectly) the text for the Custom Lineage feature. Both options are in TCoE, but they are not the same.

Custom Origins allows you to keep many of the features of a race, but swap certain things like which stat the ability modifiers are applied to, languages, and some proficiencies.(Skills, weapon proficiencies, and tools). Page 7 of TCoE.

I do find your wiki extremely helpful. Thanks.
